definitions.text: (often plural) a command given by a superior (e.g., a military or law enforcement officer) that must be obeyed
examples: the British ships dropped anchor and waited for orders from London

definitions.text: a degree in a continuum of size or quantity
examples: it was on the order of a mile
an explosion of a low order of magnitude

definitions.text: established customary state (especially of society)
examples: order ruled in the streets
law and order

definitions.text: logical or comprehensible arrangement of separate elements
examples: we shall consider these questions in the inverse order of their presentation

definitions.text: a condition of regular or proper arrangement
examples: he put his desk in order
the machine is now in working order

definitions.text: a legally binding command or decision entered on the court record (as if issued by a court or judge)
examples: a friend in New Mexico said that the order caused no trouble out there

definitions.text: a commercial document used to request someone to supply something in return for payment and providing specifications and quantities
examples: IBM received an order for a hundred computers

definitions.text: a formal association of people with similar interests
examples: he joined a golf club
they formed a small lunch society
men from the fraternal order will staff the soup kitchen today

definitions.text: a body of rules followed by an assembly
(usually plural) the status or rank or office of a Christian clergyman in an ecclesiastical hierarchy
examples: theologians still disagree over whether `bishop' should or should not be a separate Order

definitions.text: a group of person living under a religious rule
examples: the order of Saint Benedict

definitions.text: (biology) taxonomic group containing one or more families
a request for something to be made, supplied, or served
examples: I gave the waiter my order
the company's products were in such demand that they got more orders than their call center could handle

definitions.text: (architecture) one of original three styles of Greek architecture distinguished by the type of column and entablature used or a style developed from the original three by the Romans
the act of putting things in a sequential arrangement
examples: there were mistakes in the ordering of items on the list

definitions.text: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority
examples: I said to him to go home
She ordered him to do the shopping
The mother told the child to get dressed

definitions.text: make a request for something
examples: Order me some flowers
order a work stoppage

definitions.text: issue commands or orders for
bring into conformity with rules or principles or usage; impose regulations
examples: We cannot regulate the way people dress
This town likes to regulate

definitions.text: bring order to or into
examples: Order these files

definitions.text: place in a certain order
examples: order the photos chronologically

definitions.text: appoint to a clerical posts
examples: he was ordained in the Church

definitions.text: arrange thoughts, ideas, temporal events
examples: arrange my schedule
set up one's life
I put these memories with those of bygone times

definitions.text: assign a rank or rating to
examples: how would you rank these students?
The restaurant is rated highly in the food guide
